channel.title: Router
channel.description: Can an old router affect your download speed and bandwidth? Looking into buying a new router as my Internet plan is 5mb of bandwidth yet everyone on my Internet downloads at 80kb/s. Bandwidth isn't like comcast in how comcast shares bandwidth with neighbors. Also the router is extremely hot for only running like 60 volts of dc. Sometimes the Internet goes out and I think it's because the router overheats. Just making sure I'm not wasting my money in buying a new router.

item.title: Router
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:


Bit outdated, but it is the same speed. I have tested it maybe 1 month ago and it didn’t change. I even got the app on my iPod and it outputs the same data. 55kb/s upload and 70 kb/s download approx. Maybe allow 3-4 kb/s of a differential on those numbers. I’ll redo the test when I get back on my computer at my house.

Took one today:

Read full topic

item.title: Router
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

The Wanderer:

You mean through an ethernet cord right? My computer is connected directly with an ethernet cord and gets 79kb/s usually. I got an app to test the download speed of my iPod and it is the same exact speed. It fluctuates between 79 and 80 kb/s. Also our bandwidth may be more than 5mb. The plan for 5mb is $35 a month and we pay $55. Either way we should still be getting more than that. And every computer is downloading the same speed, at around 79 kb/s.

Try this; http://speedtest.net/

I’ve got a 30Mb/s connection and I’m getting around 27 - 29 MB/s (on the speedtest website)

Read full topic

You mean through an ethernet cord right? My computer is connected directly with an ethernet cord and gets 79kb/s usually. item.title: Router
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

A 5mb/s internet connection is actually represented in 5 megabits per second. They do this so it sounds like it’s more than it really is, and it’s pretty shady in my opinion. But it’s become industry standard. Divide 5,000 by 8 (there are 8 bits in a byte) and you’ll get 625kb/s which is your maximum download speed in optimal conditions.

A router can affect download speed, ping, and other things. But I wouldn’t be so quick to blame your router. Try connecting a computer directly to your modem and analyze the speeds you get then, before you invest money in a new router.

Read full topic
